title: Mozambique: Difficult to Reconcile Diplomacy With Poverty - Nyusi
text:
Mozambique: AMG Secures Funding for Ancuabe Graphite Project 
Maputo and New York — It is difficult to reconcile politics and diplomacy with poverty declared Mozambican President Filipe Nyusi in New York on Thursday night. 
At a dinner with American business people, offered by the United States Chamber of Commerce, Nyusi added that economic growth is not enough - the key factor is improving the quality of life of all Mozambicans. 
“We can make politics, we can do diplomacy, we can cooperate as we like, but as long as we are not economically firm, politics and diplomacy are unsustainable”, he said. 
The ambition of his government, Nyusi insisted, was not just to achieve economic growth, if this is not reflected in human development. 
Speaking impromptu, he stressed that the Mozambican government is not asking for support from American business people. “We have come so that we may understand and work together”, he saent for our participation in the growth of Mozambique”.id. “That's why we have brought Mozambican business people with us”. 
He regarded his meeting with the US business community as just as important as the United Nations summit he is due to attend on Friday. Nyusi stressed that his first act on American soil was to meet with American businesses. 
He was not exaggerating. Only a few minutes after his arrival in New York, Nyusi granted an audience to the vice president of the Texas-based oil and gas company Anadarko, James Kleckner. Anadarko is the operator of offshore area one of the Rovuma Basin, off the coast of the northern Mozambican province of Cabo Delgado, where vast reserves of natural gas have been found. 
“We are politicians, and our job is to create well-being for the population”, said Nyusi. “But we can only do this with a very strong business sector”. 
Nyusi took the opportunity offered by the dinner to display the economic potential of Mozambique, not merely in mineral resources, but also in such areas as tourism, agriculture and the production of energy. 
As in previous meetings of this nature, Nyusi paid special attention to agricultural development, stressed that “nobody eats gas”. 
This was an appeal for the diversification of the Mozambican economy, to avoid excessive dependence on natural gas. 
Nyusi also stressed the socio-political stability of Mozambique, assuring his audience that all the institutions of the Mozambican state are working normally. 
For his part, the co-chairperson of the Africa Business Initiative of the US Chamber of Commerce, Don Gips, praised the work undertaken by Nyusi, stressing “this is an exciting moment for our participation in the growth of Mozambique”. Mozambique
